title: Simone Biles Returns to Claim the Hardest Vault in Women’s Gymnastics History
sub_head: After a long pandemic hiatus, Biles is back—with the “Yurchenko double pike” placing a new record by her name.
body:
INDIANAPOLIS—Nineteen months after she last competed, Simone Biles has returned to claim the hardest vault in women’s gymnastics history as her reward for the delayed Olympic Games.
Biles on Saturday evening became the first female gymnast to perform a “Yurchenko double pike”—a vault that isn’t currently in the women’s rulebook and scoring system, requiring judges to assign it a provisional difficulty value of 6.6.
That score would make it the hardest vault that has ever been completed by a woman—though Biles and her coaches continue to believe it should be rated more highly still.
Biles powerfully delivered the vault at the 2021 GK U.S. Classic, where it was one of several stunning versions of the move she casually tossed out in warm-ups over the course of the event.
Her adrenaline-filled bounce on the landing, for an execution score of 9.5, suggests there is still room for improvement in her next three planned competitions: the U.S. Championships in two weeks, U.S. Olympic team trials at the end of June, and then the Olympic Games scheduled to open in Tokyo on July 23.
